comments.commentBody:
Killoran: Re: "these two athletes--in a competitive sport and funded by the public's money--did treat it like a 'fun run.' "

Yeah? Well I hereby accuse you of inordinate attraction to a fun rhyme. Since when, by the way, was the point of sport--any sport--anything BUT fun? Sure, I can well imagine someone claiming it serves this other purpose or that other purpose, but I can't imagine that someone not being completely full of it. Exercise? Discipline? Etc. (blah, blah, blah)? You don't need to race to get exercise (etc.: blah, blah, blah). The competition is precisely what makes it a game, and games are always and only for fun.

Re: "funded by the public's money"

The public funds it because the public finds it fun to have it. It's fun to watch and root; it's fun to have the entire celebration. It produces absolutely NOTHING.
A 26-mile "fun run" in the heat?  Really?

I didn't play organized sports past the age of fifteen but I do get the German "official" position: these two athletes--in a competitive sport and funded by the public's money--did treat it like a "fun run." Maybe their attitude colored their approach to the whole event. . .?

I'm amused that we Americans scoff at this and find the photo cute. We're a fiercely competitive nation and wouldn't tolerate this from our Olympic athletes.
Yeah,  but I bet you would be the first one to complain about BB point shaving, Pete Rose's betting habits, and your all time favorite boxer, no names mentioned, taking a dive.
That they clasped hands *is* their narrative. It's this entire story.

i predict the $87 million of small donations was an accounting lie to portray Trump as 'still in the running' with a groundswell of Berni- like small donor support.
-
Trump lies 80% of the time.
The $87 million was no different.
There is no $87 million to spend.
And Trump could but would not waste his own money in a sinking money pit of his campaign.

No, we all don't! We multiple birth babies don't have any personality traits in common anymore than all of you single births have a common characteristic. (Hear the absurdity of your comment when it is reflected in that way?) :-)

Twins are just folks born with someone. I'm bizygotic, not monozygotic (fraternal vs identical; 2 eggs vs 1 egg), but my mono cousins are just folks. My trip mono nieces are 3 just folks, as are their mono twin brothers :-)
Twins do stuff like that.
The $135MM sale price goes to pay Gawker's creditors, the largest of which is Hulk Hogan
Thiel funded multiple lawsuits intended to either succeed in court or run Gawker's finances low by defending against them. It's nothing like a mortgage.

In British Columbia this is what we have - one record that all health care providers csn access, which includes all prescriptions, drug allergies and labs (that even I can access) in one software system. Other countries have this too. But in the US, profits trump everything so software turf wars win over safety and convenience.

I watched it for many years as well and found him very amusing as a host. But I too eventually lost patience with the show and the predictable talking points and orthodoxy of the panelists. My favorite show is now Fareed Zakarias GPS on CNN which often has panels with liberals and conservatives but they speak in a civilized manner and I find I learn a lot more on the topic. RIP John and Bye Bye!
Dr. McLaughlin and his arch selection of pundits bestowed on me a real appreciation of the Washington D.C. 'spin' game which has unfortunately degenerated into pure banal vituperation.

Rebecca, I'm sure everyone is up to date on your recent posts.  You may not know if Kane is guilty, but the jury did.  Do you presume to know better?  And is it your position that she was convicted because she is a woman?

Robert Scribbler does indeed provide needed information that the main stream press censors.  The public is not informed for one reason; the 6 major news corporations are not reporting the facts.  Is it ignorance or deliberate? Does dark money have a hold on them?  This is the same reason we wound up in Iraq; very poor reporting to the public.

This article is pitifully self-serving.
I hope most doctors are not as preoccupied with rationalizations as this one.
My mother died as a result of three separate, preventable medical errors in three days. This was confirmed by friends who were doctors.
One contributing factor was that many doctors were away lobbying the legislature to raise the bar for medical malpractice suits. They won their fight.
My mother and our family lost ours.
To add to the pain, the doctor refused to talk with us about what we might have done differently. He refused to talk with us at all.
Does anyone take responsibility for his or her mistakes anymore?

Yes, Congress needs to answer to the people of this country and this world for denying and lying about the single biggest threat to our lives.  Many have already died and lost everything they own.  It is high time they are charged for crimes against humanity.   We are ALL effected by their criminal behavior.

I forgot to mention that, the annual flooding of this massive river system deposited enough silt to allow the "coast," if the southern delta can be called a coast, since it's mostly swamp, it allowed this area to evolve in all its swampy greatness, to form a natural barrier, a resistance to the encroachment and the onslaught of the ocean.

This barrier, as we have seen, has now been compromised. The ocean is moving inland, with areas that were less than 30 years ago above sea level now ten or more feet under water, with telephone poles sticking out of the water and residents using boats where they once drove motor vehicles on paved streets.

Read Robert Scribbler's article on the excess water vapor, which causes these rain bombs and how Co2 increases the water vapor. He writes in a manner that a lay person can understand yet backs everything up with scientific references.
This catastrophe was not accurately predicted. The heavy rain areas were supposed to be in the Midwest and upper Plains. The south was supposed to dry out.
Meteorologists were giving heavy warnings all last week and before. Given the moisture, heat, and heavy energy, it was all too likely.

May be that catastrophes like this which have been accurately predicted will move climate change deniers to rescind their opposition to reason.

If this is the case one can hope that other more obvious myths will topple as well and we can get about living like the reasonable animal life we are equipped to become.

A lot more natural disaster may have to befall us, coupled with unanswered pleas for divine intervention in order to turn the corner, but coping with natural disasters demand rationality as opposed to the irrational disaster of war.

Neither are pleasant to contemplate, but one rises to the unity of life while the other accedes to the disarray of death.

OK, I'll give it to you. Please, next time use proper quotation marks, which are " and ".

You used apostrophes. I concluded that the first was a typo and didn't notice the second.

And try prefacing the quote with a cue for readers, so we know what's coming, such as, "The true believers say,...." I wrote professionally for many decades and will vouch for the importance of that technique.

I agree with many of your points....I would, however, dispute the statement that areas that are not floodplains flooded here. In reality, these areas ARE floodplains, they are just considered (by FEMA and local development regulatory overseers) as being flooded just infrequently enough that they do not require flood insurance. The fallacy that the lack of NFIP requirement must mean that a home is not in a floodplain is a disastrous falsehood to fall prey to. This is a widespread belief that must be debunked.... the one silver lining of these (once?) rare floods is to shed light on this mis-education. To think that folks here in soggy and flat LA, of all places, have this mindset really goes to show you how large of a hurdle this will be to overcome.

I, for one, think that one day of gutting a flooded house is more than enough...not looking to have to repeat this shutting soon.

I am hopeful for a speedy recovery for your loved ones and mine.

Not much of a scientist but you have to be pretty ignorant or deluded not to understand the facts in this article, especially the idea that warmer air holds more water and that several places on the planet are suddenly experiencing off the charts rainfall and flooding--how much evidence do we need? One more good reason to send the ant-science, irrational Trump back to stupid tv
"reality."

What I found particularly useful was the scale of clean energy that is needed. We are just diddling with this, and that will not be enough. It can be done.

http://www.withouthotair.com/

Unfortunately, the English-speaking part of the world has been too casual about picking up the pace, while pushing fracking, which arguably doesn't help at all, as the accounting does not count all its costs. And pellet fuel is a travesty; at first it was supposed to be waste, but you can imagine that growing forests for export to make pellets is not woriking at all, which is what happens when you scale it up.

"Sustainable energy without the hot air" by the Cambridge physicist and UK dept. of Climate Change director, David Mackay is the clearest guide to action. He was a lifelong teacher who didnt want to give people the
"answers", but the tools to think for themselves and analyse a situation. Please do read his great book freely available online. And use his physics-informed analysis to retool your lifestyle and make the most effective choices to reduce your personal energy consumption. Americans after all consume 2X more energy per capita than Germany and other OECD countries:
1. Reduce your flying. In a single transatlantic flight you consume as much energy as leaving a typical AC switched on for an entire year. See https://www.withouthotair.com/c5/page_35.shtml
2. Reduce/increase your thermostat in the summer/winter. The typical home's energy consumption drops by 10% for each 1 degC change in thermostat. Insulate your homes.
3. Eliminate food waste. Food wasted is multiplied energy and water waste.

Lastly, dont be distracted by the myth that "every little helps". Seek out effective solutions to reduce energy consumption. As David often said "If everyone does a little, we'll achieve only a little"

"Along the delta, the river has not been able to flood annually, spreading silt along its banks as it has done for millennia."

Oh, and I also forgot to mention one more thing. The flood plains that people use to avoid, they have now been developed, Dams and levees created these areas and their development has not been a good idea. These areas will be the first to go, with dire consequences, when the levees break.

We think we can control this mighty river. It is only a matter of time before the same type of torrential rains that, say 100 years ago, would have caused "flooding" here and there, but nothing out of the ordinary for those familiar with it, will wreak havoc in ways in which people are not familiar and for which they are woefully unprepared. We used to know not to build on the flood plain of great rivers and next to the ocean. We now think we can get away with it. But we can't. Flood plain development means "where will we release the water, from what gate / dam / levee will the pressure be relieved." And you better hope you're not in the way of that release.

I was raised in both the Midwest and west. We moved to Northern California when I was in middle school and it was instantly recognizable to me that people cared much less about money and material things than they did in the Midwest. Many very wealthy families lived in small houses and drove old cars. Friend groups were very diverse in both ethnicity and socioeconomic status. People were welcomed and accepted immediately. After returning to the Midwest (but a different town) it took a couple of years to break into a social group and people were aware of other people's houses,cars etc. Social competition was high.

I now live again in Northern California, and thankfully don't have this madness occurring in our elementary school. Thus, I am wondering if some of this might be more of a regional phenomenon?
Both.
@Joe:  These people are undergoing a(nother) disaster, this is hardly the time for political sniping.
